summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing a FOIA lawsuit filed by The New York Times against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) for records related to Jeffrey Epstein. It also references the coordination of 'Touhy requests' (requests for government information in third-party litigation) from civil plaintiffs/victims in Epstein-related lawsuits, designating a point person for such requests.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney at Kaplan & Hecker representing plaintiffs/victims in civil litigation related to Jeffrey Epstein. The email states she will be contacted regarding the process for making Touhy requests.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure whose records are being sought via FOIA and Touhy requests. The document concerns government records related to him and litigation stemming from his actions.

connections.description: Kaplan is identified as counsel for plaintiffs (alleged victims) in civil lawsuits related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: NY Times Files FOIA Complaint Against BOP
events.description: The New York Times files a FOIA lawsuit challenging the Bureau of Prisons' response (or lack thereof) to the Times's FOIA requests for records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Coordination on Epstein-Related Touhy Requests
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discuss and establish a process for handling Touhy requests (for government information) from civil plaintiffs/victims in Epstein-related litigation, designating a point person.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA lawsuit against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) for failing to adequately respond to requests for Jeffrey Epstein-related records.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was coordinating its response to 'Touhy requests' (formal requests for government information in third-party litigation) related to Epstein.
Robbie Kaplan of Kaplan & Hecker was identified as counsel for plaintiffs (alleged victims) in civil Epstein litigation who would be making such Touhy requests.
The email chain shows internal DOJ procedural coordination between criminal and civil divisions regarding the release of information from the Epstein investigation.
The document references the legal standards and privileges (e.g., law enforcement privilege) that govern the disclosure of information from criminal investigations in unrelated civil litigation.
